Coding explanation: Algeria is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Barbary_War) [sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Algeria) state that slavery was curtailed in 1816 and 1848. We conservatively code the later year.

Armenia is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Austria isn't covered by V-Dem between 1939 and 1944. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. During that time, Austria was a part of Germany, so we use Germany's end year.

Azerbaijan is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Bangladesh is covered by V-Dem only from 1971. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Pakistan, which had large-scale forced labor in 1970. So we use that year.

Belarus is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Belgium isn't covered by V-Dem between 1796 and 1829. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. During that time, Belgium was first a part of France and then of the Netherlands. V-Dem's expert assessments and our cutoff suggest there was no large-scale forced labor in these countries then either. So we code that large-scale forced labor ended before 1789.

Bosnia and Herzegovina is covered by V-Dem only from 1992. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

Bulgaria is covered by V-Dem only from 1878. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Ottoman Empire, which had large-scale forced labor in 1877. So we use that year.

Burundi is covered by V-Dem only from 1915. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.britannica.com/place/Burundi/History) [sources](https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/abs/slavery-in-the-great-lakes-region-of-east-africa/slave-trade-in-burundi-rwanda-at-the-beginning-of-german-colonisation-1890-1906/282429AAADA317D47A0C06EF8B8E37FA) are unclear about the scale of forced labor during the 19th and early 20th centuries. We conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Cameroon is covered by V-Dem only from 1960. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01440399808575243) [sources](https://archive.org/details/historicaldictio0000dela_t6l4/page/500/mode/2up) state that slavery existed in the late colonial era. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Canada is covered by V-Dem only from 1841. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Canada) [sources](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavery-Abolition-Act) state that slavery was abolished in 1833. We therefore code that year.

Chart annotation: After Mao's death, China's large system of [forced](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Re-education_through_labor) [labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laogai) was weakened. However, forms persist to this day, such as coercion of the [Uyghur](https://www.ohchr.org/sites/default/files/documents/countries/2022-08-31/22-08-31-final-assesment.pdf) [minority](https://www.walkfree.org/global-slavery-index/country-studies/china/).

Coding explanation: Costa Rica is covered by V-Dem only from 1838. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was a part of the Captaincy General of Guatemala and the United Provinces of Central America, so we use code the end year there. There is a single-year gap in the data in 1822, but because the precise expert scores are very similar before and after, we conservatively assume there was no major change then.

Croatia is covered by V-Dem only from 1991. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

Cyprus is covered by V-Dem only from 1914. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Ottoman Empire, so we use the last year of large-scale forced labor in the Ottoman Empire before 1914.

Estonia is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Fiji is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/how-blackbirders-forced-tens-of-thousands-of-pacific-islanders-into-slavery-after-the-civil-war-180985567/) [sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackbirding#Fiji) suggest that forced labor existed in the late 19th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Finland is covered by V-Dem only from 1809. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Sweden, which didn't have large-scale forced labor either. So we code that large-scale forced labor ended before 1789.

There is a two-year gap in V-Dem's France data for men in 1791 and 1792. Based on V-Dem's expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Because the precise expert scores for women improve during those years, women's score in 1789 and 1790 were worse than those for men, and we didn't find any information to suggest otherwise, we conservatively assume there was no major change then.

Georgia is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Germany isn't covered by V-Dem between 1945 and 1949. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. During that time, Germany was occupied by the Allies. Although those engaged in some forced labor, this [predominantly affects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forced_labor_of_Germans_after_World_War_II) German prisoners of war abroad, not in Germany itself. We therefore code the last year of Nazi rule.
Chart annotation: The fall of the Nazi regime ended a system that forced an estimated [15 million](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forced_labour_under_German_rule_during_World_War_II) people to work under [brutal conditions](https://encyclopedia.ushmm.org/content/en/article/forced-labor-an-overview).

Coding explanation: Guyana is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Guyana#Colonial_Guyana) [sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_Abolition_Act_1833) state that slavery was abolished in 1833. We therefore code that year.

Honduras is covered by V-Dem only from 1838. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was a part of the Captaincy General of Guatemala and the United Provinces of Central America, so we use code the end year there. There is a single-year gap in the data in 1822, but because the precise expert scores are very similar before and after, we conservatively assume there was no major change then.

Iceland is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vistarband) [sources](https://rafhladan.is/bitstream/handle/10802/33241/Contested%20Households%20%20Lodgers%20%20Labour%20%20and%20the%20Law%20in%20Rural%20Iceland%20in%20the%20Early%2019th%20Century.pdf?sequence=1) suggest that a compulsory labor system was curtailed in 1863 and 1894. We therefore conservatively code the later year.

Iraq is covered by V-Dem only from 1920. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Ottoman Empire, so we use the Ottoman Empire's end year.

Ireland is covered by V-Dem only from 1919. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Great Britain, so we use Great Britain's end year.

Israel is covered by V-Dem only from 1947. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Palestine) [sources](https://www.britannica.com/place/Palestine/World-War-I-and-after) suggest there was no large-scale forced labor during the mandate. We therefore use the Ottoman Empire's end year.

Italy is covered by V-Dem only from 1861. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, the most important Italian state was Piedmont-Sardinia, so we use Piedmont-Sardinia's end year.

Jamaica is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Jamaica) [sources](https://www.jstor.org/stable/40652579) state that slavery was abolished in 1833. We therefore code that year.

Jordan is covered by V-Dem only from 1922. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was a part of the Ottoman Empire, but there is a two-year gap in the data in 1920 and 1921. Because the precise expert scores are very similar before and after, and the period is described as an ["interregnum"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interregnum_(Transjordan)), we conservatively assume there was no major change then, and use the Ottoman Empire's end year.

Kazakhstan is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Chart annotation: Kenya gained independence from Britain, bringing an end to its [colonial](https://www.penguin.co.uk/books/362366/britains-gulag-by-elkins-caroline/9781529946185) [forced](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mau_Mau_rebellion) [labor](https://content.e-bookshelf.de/media/reading/L-12349100-ba6ffbc51c.pdf) system.

Coding explanation: Kosovo is covered by V-Dem only from 1999. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

Kyrgyzstan is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Latvia is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Lebanon is covered by V-Dem only from 1918. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Ottoman Empire, which had large-scale forced labor in 1917. So we use that year.

Lesotho is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.jstor.org/stable/26846881) [sources](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/0144039X.2022.2063232) are unclear about the scale of forced labor in the first half of the 19th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Libya isn't covered by V-Dem between 1941 and 1950. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. During that time, Libya was first a colony of Italy and then occupied by France and the United Kingdom. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Libya) [sources](https://www.countrystudies.us/libya/25.htm) are unclear about the scale of forced labor during those years. We therefore conservatively code the last year before V-Dem covers the country again.

Lithuania is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Luxembourg is covered by V-Dem only from 1815. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was first a part of Austria and then of France. We therefore use the last year of large-scale forced labor in Austria before then.

The Maldives are covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://bpb-us-e2.wpmucdn.com/sites.uci.edu/dist/6/3310/files/2018/04/A-supply-side-aspect-of-the-African-slave-trade-The-cowrie-production-and-exports-of-the-Maldives.pdf?trk=public_post_comment-tex) [sources](https://scholarlypublications.universiteitleiden.nl/access/item%3A3139955/view) suggest that forced labor was rare then. We therefore assume large-scale forced labor ended before 1789.

Malta is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Malta#French_occupation_(1798%E2%80%931800)) [sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Malta) state that slavery was abolished in 1798. We therefore code that year.

Mauritius is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Mauritius#British_rule_(1810%E2%80%931968)) [sources](https://www.britannica.com/place/Mauritius/The-arts-and-cultural-institutions#ref4723) state that slavery was abolished in 1835. We therefore code that year.

Chart annotation: The start of the Mexican Revolution brought an end to the [coercive labor system](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/abs/coercion-culture-and-contracts-labor-and-debt-on-henequen-haciendas-in-yucatan-mexico-18701915/F309D785BC3B1D9C171F70255AB31FFC) that had continued after slavery had been [formally abolished](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_New_Spain).

Coding explanation: Moldova is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Montenegro is covered by V-Dem only from 1998. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

New Zealand is covered by V-Dem only from 1841. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.theprow.org.nz/maori/slavery-in-colonial-times/) [sources](https://teara.govt.nz/en/turanga-i-te-hapori-status-in-maori-society/print) are unclear about the extent of forced labor in the first half of the 19th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Nigeria is covered by V-Dem only from 1914. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.britannica.com/place/Nigeria/The-arrival-of-the-British) [sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Nigeria) are unclear about the extent of forced labor in the early 20th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

North Macedonia is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

Panama is covered by V-Dem only from 1903. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Colombia, which had large-scale forced labor in 1902. So we use that year.

Libya was first a colony of Italy and then occupied by France and the United Kingdom. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Libya) [sources](https://www.countrystudies.us/libya/25.htm) are unclear about the scale of forced labor during those years. We therefore conservatively code the last year before V-Dem covers the country again.

Poland isn't covered by V-Dem between 1939 and 1943. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. During that time, it was a part of Germany and the Soviet Union. Because both these countries had large-scale forced labor during that time, including in their [Polish territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Poland_(1939%E2%80%931945)), we code the last year of their occupation.

Chart annotation: The Soviet Union substantially scaled back its [Gulags](https://www.britannica.com/place/Gulag) after Stalin's death. An estimated [18 million people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulag) were forced to work in them, and over [a million people](https://www.britannica.com/place/Gulag) died there.

Coding explanation: Senegal is covered by V-Dem only from 1904. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-01736-6) [sources](https://sites.ohio.edu/chastain/rz/senegal.htm) suggest that forced labor continued into the beginning of the 20th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

The Seychelles are covered by V-Dem only from 1903. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Seychelles) [sources](http://seychellesnationalmuseums.org/exhibitions/slavery/) state that slavery was abolished in 1835. We therefore code that year.

Slovakia is covered by V-Dem only from 1993. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Czechoslovakia, so we use Czechoslovakia's end year.

Slovenia is covered by V-Dem only from 1989. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of Yugoslavia, so we use Yugoslavia's end year.

The Solomon Islands are covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackbirding) [sources](https://www.britannica.com/place/Solomon-Islands/History#ref344509) are unclear about the extent of forced labor in the late 19th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

Sri Lanka is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://www.britannica.com/place/Sri-Lanka/British-Ceylon-1796-1900) [sources](https://hrlibrary.umn.edu/research/srilanka/statutes/Abolition_of_Slavery_Ordinance.pdf) state that slavery was abolished in 1844. We therefore code that year.

Suriname is covered by V-Dem only from 1900. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ketikoti) [sources](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01440399308575085) state that slavery was curtailed in 1863 and 1873. We therefore conservatively code the later year.

Switzerland is covered by V-Dem only from 1798. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Because the precise expert scores indicate that forced labor was rare at the end of the 18th century, and the founding of the Helvetic Republic does not seem to have changed [labor relations](https://www.britannica.com/place/Switzerland/The-Helvetic-Republic) much, we assume that large-scale forced labor ended before 1789.

Syria is covered by V-Dem only from 1922. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was a part of the Ottoman Empire, but there is a two-year gap in the data in 1920 and 1921. Because the precise expert scores are very similar before and after, and the years formed a [transition phase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandate_for_Syria_and_the_Lebanon), we conservatively assume there was no major change then, and use the Ottoman Empire's end year.

Tajikistan is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Tanzania is covered by V-Dem only from 1914. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Zanzibar#Abolition_and_aftermath) [sources](https://discovery.ucl.ac.uk/id/eprint/10189196/1/the-sultans-of-zanzibar-and-the-abolition-of-slavery-in-east-africa.pdf) state that slavery was curtailed in 1897 and 1909. We therefore conservatively code the later year.

Turkmenistan is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Ukraine is covered by V-Dem only from 1990. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. Before that, it was part of the Soviet Union, so we use the Soviet Union's end year.

Chart annotation: The [Slavery Abolition Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_Abolition_Act_1833) ended slavery in most of the British Empire, freeing [hundreds of thousands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_Abolition_Act_1833) from plantations and private estates. However, other forced labor systems [continued](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery_in_Britain) in many of its colonies.

Slavery in the United States [ended](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution) [after](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1866) the Civil War. About [four million](https://www.census.gov/about/history/stories/monthly/2025/june-2025.html) people were freed.

Coding explanation: Vanuatu is covered by V-Dem only from 1906. Based on its expert assessments and our cutoff, there was no large-scale forced labor since then. [Additional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanuatu#Arrival_of_Europeans_(1606%E2%80%931906)) [sources](https://www.britannica.com/place/Vanuatu/History) are unclear about the extent of forced labor in the late 19th and early 20th century. We therefore conservatively code the last year before the V-Dem data starts.

After Mao's death, China's large system of [forced](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Re-education_through_labor) [labor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laogai) was weakened. However, forms persist to this day, such as coercion of the [Uyghur](https://www.ohchr.org/sites/default/files/documents/countries/2022-08-31/22-08-31-final-assesment.pdf) [minority](https://www.walkfree.org/global-slavery-index/country-studies/china/).
